abstract.p: Letter from General Motors chairman, John F Smith, on June 21 article says school-to-work partnerships between businesses and schools play vital work in matching skills with job requirements

block.p: ''Schools Turning From Teaching Trades'' (front page, June 21) did not mention the trend of school-to-work partnerships between businesses and schools. ''Schools Turning From Teaching Trades'' (front page, June 21) did not mention the trend of school-to-work partnerships between businesses and schools. One study predicts that by the year 2005, only 21 percent of the jobs generated in this country will require a college degree. School-to-work partnerships play a vital role in matching skills with job requirements.

One example is the nationwide Automotive Youth Education Systems program, co-sponsored by automakers and dealerships. Students carry a full academic workload and are guaranteed a job at the local dealership upon completing the program -- a strong incentive to finish school. There are 175 schools and 1,660 dealerships in 31 states now taking part.
This kind of training is compatible with a solid academic education and is essential to meeting the nation's needs.
JOHN F. SMITH Chairman, General Motors Detroit, June 26, 2000
